newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil's Bozano silent on audit of Banerj.
newsitem.headline: Brazil's Bozano silent on audit of Banerj.

text.p: Brazilian investment bank Bozano, Simonsen Friday declined to comment on press reports that Rio de Janeiro state bank Banerj will be audited.
"We will not comment on the reports for the time being," a Bozano spokesman said.

Newspapers today said Rio de Janeiro's state Accounting Office (TCE) has ordered an in depth audit of Banerj, which has been managed by Bozano, to see if its administrator committed any irregularities.
The Accounting Office accuses Bozano of refusing to provide information on Banerj's financial situation, which forms the basis for its remuneration for managing the state bank, O Globo daily said.
Early this year Bozano was awarded a contract for managing the bank, replacing the Central Bank, and readying it for privatization in 1997.
Paulo Ferraz, Bozano's president, had told reporters Banerj showed 400,000 reais in operating income for the month of June and it was ready to be privatized this year.

Under its plan to prepare the state bank for sell-off, Bozano closed 27 Banerj's branches, reducing its network to 193 outlets from 220, and cut the bank's staff to 8,000 employees from 11,500 employees.
He also had said Banerj's time deposits had increased to 1.060 billion reais in June from 490 million reais in December 1995.
